title: Making Meta | Andrew ‘Boz’ Bosworth (CTO)
key_insights: Communication is the job - success depends entirely on how effectively you communicate your ideas and vision to others
Leverage your leaders more - ask for help early and often, most managers want you to succeed and can clear obstacles
Optimize for learning over short-term career advancement - variety of experience compounds over time
When facing identity threat, embrace curiosity instead of defensiveness - ask 'fascinating, tell me more'
You know more than external critics about your own company/work - don't blindly accept outside narratives
Focus on strengths over weaknesses when building teams and developing careers
Transparency at scale requires teaching people how to filter signal from noise
Early startup success requires extreme sacrifice but isn't as glamorous as portrayed in media
topics_discussed: Early days at Facebook as 10th engineer
Building Facebook News Feed and its initial backlash
Meta's recent turnaround and organizational changes
Apple Vision Pro vs Quest comparison
Managing identity threat and ego in professional settings
The importance of curiosity over defensiveness
memorable_quotes: Communication is the job. If you want to have an impact on the world around you, it is exclusively done through the creation of artifacts or verbalizations that affect other humans.
You're never as good as they say you are when you're winning, and you're never as bad as they say you are when you're losing.
Fascinating. You have to tell me more about why you think that. - The power of curiosity over defensiveness when facing disagreement
frameworks_mentioned: HPMs (Highlight, People, Me) - weekly update format
Eye of Sauron - metaphor for executive attention
Gell-Mann Amnesia - selective skepticism of media
summary: Meta CTO Andrew 'Boz' Bosworth shares hard-won lessons from 18 years at Facebook/Meta, covering everything from the intense early startup days to building breakthrough products like News Feed. The conversation provides tactical advice on communication, leadership, and career growth, emphasizing the importance of leveraging managers, embracing curiosity over defensiveness, and understanding that effective communication is the foundation of all professional success.
